ISSUE.TITLE: Change quadlet-generator to ignore missing `/run/containers/systemd` directory
ISSUE.DESCRIPTION: ### Feature request description As I'm working with Quadlets, I've been seeing this "lstat error": [root ~]# /usr/libexec/podman/quadlet -dryrun quadlet-generator[18301]: Error occurred resolving path "/run/containers/systemd": lstat /run/containers/systemd: no such file or directory quadlet-generator[18301]: No files parsed from [/run/containers/systemd /etc/containers/systemd /usr/share/containers/systemd] This leads me to questions like "well, why doesn't it exist?" and "who is responsible for creating it?" Being a busy guy, I've just been silencing it with a quick `mkdir` which of course only works until a reboot and `/run` gets reset. [root ~]# mkdir /run/containers/systemd ### Suggest potential solution I just took a minute to look into it further and it appears to me that the directory missing is not really an *error* condition, and based on #23363 I'm guessing that the user is responsible for creating it if they want it to be used. If these both are true statements, can quadlet-generator be changed to silently ignore when this particular directory is missing? Or log it as a "notice"? ### Have you considered any alternatives? I can use `mkdir` when I'm testing manually but the error will still show up in the boot log. ### Additional context I suspect to a lot of people "error" means "something is broken, you may want to fix it" so ultimately I'm looking for the proper fix

BUGGYCOMMIT.MESSAGE: Merge pull request #23960 from eriksjolund/troubleshooting-user-containers troubleshooting: add tip about the user containers

COMMIT.MESSAGE: quadlet: do not log ENOENT errors There is no point in logging them, the directories not existing is fine and expected and logging these by default when useing -dryrun just causes confusion. Fixes #23620 Signed-off-by: Paul Holzinger <pholzing@redhat.com>
